plant_concentrations.Value: Tri-p-cresyl phosphate was detected in the shoot 1.72 ug/g, pod 0.09 ug/g, leaf 1.14 ug/g, and stem 6.28 ug/g of soybean plants grown 90 days in soil containing tri-p-cresyl phosphate(1).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Cho KJ et al; Water Sci Technol 30: 189-97 (1994) (2) Howard PH, Deo PG; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 22: 337-44 (1979) (3) Ku Y, Alvarez GH; Appl Environ Microbiol 43: 619-22 (1982) (4) Sasaki S; pp. 283-98 in Aquatic Pollutants: Transformation and Biological Effects. Hutzinger O et al eds. Oxford: Pergamon Press (1978)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Biodegradation of tri-p-cresyl phosphate in river water and bottom sediment followed first-order kinetics(1). The first-order rate constant in river water ranged from approximately 0.0073 per hour at 14 °C to 0.0091 per hour at 25 °C(1); this corresponds to a half-life of about 4 days at 14 °C and 3.2 days at 25 °C(SRC). The first-order rate constant in bottom sediment ranged from approximately 0.0043 per hour at 14 °C to 0.0055 per hour at 25 °C(1); this corresponds to a half-life of about 6.7 days at 14 °C and 5.3 days at 25 °C(SRC). The half-life of tri-p-cresyl phosphate in Lake Ontario water, following a lag period of 2 days, was 2 days(2). In a laboratory model sewage treatment system 70 to 80% of methyl C-14 tri-p-cresyl phosphate added at 1 ug/ml was degraded in 24 hours using an activated sludge seed; the major metabolite was identified as p-hydroxybenzoic acid(3). In biodegradation tests using an activated sludge seed, tri-p-cresyl phosphate was observed to be biodegradable(4).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Cho KJ et al; Water Sci Technol 30: 189-97 (1994)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: Tricresyl phosphate, unspecified isomer, was detected in Detroit river sediments at concentrations ranging from 0.23 to 1.30 ug/L(1). Tri-p-cresyl phosphate was detected in bottom sediment from the Kurose River, Japan at concentrations ranging from 0.003 ug/g in April 1992 to 0.03 ug/g in July 1992(1).

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.10. Jan, 2011. Available from, as of Oct 2, 2012: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm (2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 23 (1983) (3) Takimoto K et al; Environ Sci Technol 32: 3907-3912 (1998) (4) Cho KM et al; Wat Sci Tech 30: 189-197 (1994)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Using a structure estimation method based on molecular connectivity indices(1), the Koc for tri-p-cresyl phosphate can be estimated to be 4.4X10+4(SRC). According to a recommended classification scheme(2), this estimated Koc value suggests that tri-p-cresyl phosphate is expected to be immobile in soil(SRC). Tri-p-cresyl phosphate was found to adsorb strongly to clay minerals in sorption tests(3). Using bottom sediment from a river, tri-p-cresyl phosphate was found to adsorb strongly to the sediment with a Freundlich isotherm constant of 138(4); it was further observed that tri-p-cresyl phosphate in the water column adsorbed to sediment and precipitated to the bottom(4).
